reasoning: I examined the activation patterns across all 10 examples, focusing on when and where strong feature activations occurred. I looked for correlations between activation peaks and annotated genomic elements, paying close attention to recurring patterns across multiple samples.
findings: The feature shows strong, consistent activation patterns corresponding to CRISPR elements (repeats and spacers) in bacterial genomes. In sections 1, 2, and 3, activation peaks directly overlap with annotated CRISPR repeats. The activation pattern typically appears as concentrated clusters of high-amplitude spikes (2-4 on scale) or as continuous regions of activity. Notably, in section 2 we see both a CRISPR repeat annotation (ID 1 and 3) with corresponding activation. In section 3, the feature activates strongly near a CRISPR spacer (ID 6). The intensity of activation suggests this feature is specifically tuned to detect CRISPR-associated sequences, which are critical components of bacterial adaptive immunity systems.
conclusion: This feature reliably detects CRISPR elements across diverse bacterial genomes, representing a biologically meaningful pattern with functional significance.
title: CRISPR repeat element detector
description: This feature specifically detects CRISPR (Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats) elements in bacterial genomes, primarily focusing on CRISPR repeats and adjacent regions. The feature shows distinctive spike patterns of high intensity (2-4 units) directly at or near annotated CRISPR elements. CRISPR systems function as adaptive immune mechanisms in bacteria and archaea, providing defense against foreign genetic elements like phages. The feature's consistent activation across multiple examples and different genomic contexts suggests it has learned the characteristic sequence signatures of these elements. This detection capability could be valuable for identifying unannotated CRISPR systems in novel bacterial genomes and understanding bacterial defense mechanisms.
